snippet: Sony, the struggling Japanese electronics company, is trying hard to get your attention. It can't resist highlighting big numbers for the features inside its products. The company introduced its newest Android phone, the Xperia Z, which has a 13-m...
abstract: Sony, the struggling Japanese electronics company, is trying hard to get your attention. It can't resist highlighting big numbers for the features inside its products. The company introduced its newest Android phone, the Xperia Z, which has a 13-megapixel camera, along with two Ultra High-Definition TVs.

headline.main: C.E.S. 2013: For Sony, the More Pixels the Better

snippet: Devices like tablets and smartphones have transformed the way people use the Internet, making the dominance of a company like Google potentially more precarious than it seems.
abstract: Devices like tablets and smartphones have transformed how people use the Internet, making dominance of company like Google potentially more precarious than it seems; Google has 96 percent of world's mobile search market, but that could decline as people change their mobile search habits.

headline.main: Mobile Apps Drive Rapid Change in Searches
headline.print_headline: Mobile Apps Drive Rapid Change in Searches

snippet: Evernote has always been useful as a way to record recipes and restaurants. But Evernote Food, a revised app from the same company, does an even better job.
abstract: Evernote has always been useful as a way to record recipes and restaurants. But Evernote Food, a revised app from the same company, does an even better job.

snippet: Their expense has so far made them rare, but with prices coming down, these glowing, programmable spheres are set to become more common.
abstract: Digital globes, which rely on projection and a spherical screen, display political boundaries and topography as well as complex phenomena such as weather patterns; globes may become more widely available as prices fall.

headline.main: Digital Globes Offer a Dynamic Vision
headline.print_headline: Digital Globes Offer a Dynamic Vision

snippet: How can hardware companies make their products stand out in a sea of screens? That challenge will be on display this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Brian X. Chen reports in Monday's New York Times. And it is one that is partic...
abstract: How can hardware companies make their products stand out in a sea of screens? That challenge will be on display this week at the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, Brian X. Chen reports in Monday's New York Times. And it is one that is particularly acute for television makers.

headline.main: Daily Report: Making Screens That Will Stand Out at C.E.S.

snippet: In any given year, at least eight million vocational students work on assembly lines and workshops, according to estimates from the Ministry of Education.

headline.main: Students by Millions Fill Labor Gap in China
headline.print_headline: Students by Millions Fill Labor Gap in China

snippet: MediaTek of Taiwan not only provides manufacturers with chips for their smartphones but also tells how to build and run them, cutting their costs as they compete with the iPhone.
abstract: MediaTek of Taiwan not only provides manufacturers with chips for their smartphones but also offers instructions on how to build and run them, cutting their costs as they compete with Apple's iPhone; firm has 50 percent of China's smartphone chip market.

headline.main: Providing a Template to Challenge Apple
headline.print_headline: MediaTek Chips Change China’s Smartphone Market

snippet: Television makers are trying to attract attention by supersizing screens and quadrupling the level of detail in images, and they are adding apps and other interactive elements.
abstract: Television makers, facing crowded field and competition from other devices, are trying to attract attention by supersizing screens and quadrupling the level of detail in images; manufacturers are also pushing the idea of 'smart' sets by adding apps and other interactive features.

headline.main: As Sales Slip, TV Makers Strain for the Next Sensation
headline.print_headline: As Sales Slip, TV Makers Strain for the Next Sensation

snippet: For the time being, the sky over traditional media is blue and it’s raining green.
abstract: David Carr The Media Equations column notes that traditional media companies performed surprisingly well in 2012 despite host of market challenges and widespread opinion that they have become outmoded; contends that companies' stocks climbed due to excellent long-term financial decisions and income from steady stream of fees.

snippet: The opening of an office in Lower Manhattan gives Goodby, Silverstein & Partners a presence in New York, the capital of advertising, for the first time.
abstract: Stuart Elliott Advertising column; San Francisco firm Goodby, Silverstein & Partners will open Manhattan office, giving them a presence in the advertising capital for the first time.

headline.main: An Agency a Continent Away Expands to the Ad Capital
headline.print_headline: An Agency a Continent Away Expands to the Ad Capital
